A 20 nm spin Hall nano-oscillator
Philipp Dürrenfeld,*a,b Ahmad A. Awad,b Afshin Houshang,b Randy K. Dumasb and Johan Åkermanb,c
Spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNOs) are an emerging class of pure spin current driven microwave signal
generators. Through the fabrication of 20 nm nano-constrictions in Pt/NiFe bilayers, we demonstrate that
SHNOs can be scaled down to truly nanoscopic dimensions, with the added benefit of ultra-low operat-
ing currents and improved power conversion efficiency. The lateral confinement leads to a strong shape
anisotropy field as well as an additional demagnetizing field whose reduction with increasing auto-
oscillation amplitude can yield a positive current tunability contrary to the negative tunability commonly
observed for localized excitations in extended magnetic layers. Micromagnetic simulations corroborate
the experimental findings and suggest that the active magnetodynamic area resides up to 100 nm outside
of the nano-constriction.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The excitation and manipulation of spin waves has garnered large interest over the past years and has led to the emergence of the burgeoning field of magnonics.1–3 Communication and computation applications purely based on spin waves have been envisioned,4–10 with much lower energy consumption than current, or even future, CMOS logic where only the charge of the electron is utilized. Spin transfer torque (STT) driven magnetization dynamics are promising for these applications due to their intrinsically nanoscale nature.11–15 Nanocontact spin torque oscillators (NC-STOs) are particularly promising, as their geometry of a nanoscopic contact on top of an extended magnetic layer allows them to excite a wide variety of spin wave modes, e.g., propagating spin waves,16–18 localized spin wave bullets,19–24 droplet solitons,25–28 and dynamically stabilized skyrmions.29 NC-STOs have also been implemented to inject spin waves into nanomagnonic waveguides, either operating with spin polarized currents30 or with pure spin currents.31
With the recent advent and utilization of the spin Hall effect (SHE),32–35 the potential for STT based microwave and magnonic devices has increased substantially. Through asymmetric electron scattering in a non-magnetic metal with high spin–orbit interaction, the SHE converts a lateral un-polarized
charge current into a transverse pure spin current. In a nonmagnetic/ferromagnetic bilayer, the generated spin current can then exert a substantial STT on the ferromagnetic layer.36,37 Above a certain critical current, the STT can fully compensate the local spin wave damping and auto-oscillations can be sustained.38
The corresponding microwave signal generators, so-called spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNOs),39–46 exhibit a number of advantages compared to NC-STOs, including easier nano-fabrication, reduced currents through the magnetic layers, and direct optical access to the magnetodynamically active area. Since no net charge current is required to flow between the two layers, the SHE also opens up the possibility of using ferromagnetic insulator materials, e.g., yttrium iron garnet (YIG), in STOs.47–49
It was recently demonstrated that a 150 nm wide nanoconstriction defined in a platinum/permalloy (Py) bilayer can concentrate the current sufficiently to generate auto-oscillations at room temperature and for relatively small in-plane magnetic fields.43 Here, we report on spin wave excitations in similar nano-constriction based SHNOs with a much lower minimum dimension of 20 nm, which leads to a drastically reduced threshold current. We additionally show that operation in out-of-plane fields yields microwave signals with a much lower linewidth and with frequencies that are tunable over a range of more than 10 GHz.

sapphire C-plane substrate at room temperature using a magnetron sputtering system with a base pressure of lower than 3 × 10−8 Torr. The SHNOs are designed as 4 μm × 12 μm rectangles with two 50 nm tip radii indentations forming nanoconstrictions with nominal widths ranging from 50 to 300 nm. These patterns were written into the negative electron beam lithography (EBL) resist ma-N 2401. The pattern transfer into the bilayer was then achieved by ion beam etching using the negative resist as the etching mask. By taking advantage of ion beam etching at a tilted angle of 25° with respect to the film normal and the concomitant lateral erosion of the etching mask, the constriction sizes were consistently reduced up to 30 nm from their nominal values as measured by scanning electron microscopy. The smallest devices therefore have a minimum constriction width of ∼20 nm, as can be seen in the inset of Fig. 1(b). The devices are then protected from oxidation by a sputter-deposited 45 nm thick SiO2 layer. Finally, coplanar waveguides facilitate electrical measurements and are fabricated by optical lithography, dry etching of the protective SiO2 layer, and subsequent lift-off of 1 μm copper and 20 nm gold.
The two-point resistance of the devices as a function of the nominal nano-constriction width is plotted in Fig. 1(c) and is found to be approximately inversely proportional to the nominal nano-constriction size, diverging for a design size of ∼30 nm, in agreement with the 30 nm shrinkage due to the ion beam etching discussed above. From nominally similar devices with an actual nano-constriction width >20 nm, essentially all showed a consistent behavior in terms of resistance and microwave signal emission, whereas the yield for the 20 nm SHNOs was about 25%, with the rest exhibiting unreasonably high resistances due to the nano-constrictions being probably damaged or broken. However, all yielding devices exhibited both a tight resistance distribution and very consistent microwave signal characteristics, regardless of size.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In-plane angular dependent anisotropic magnetoresistance (AMR) measurements were performed at room temperature
with a current of 0.1 mA on a 20 nm nano-constriction device, see Fig. 1(d). We used a rotatable projected field magnet with a constant field strength of 90 mT where the in-plane field angle φ = 0° is defined as the current and magnetic field being perpendicular (minimum resistance), as indicated in the schematic drawing of Fig. 1(a). An overall AMR of 0.17% is found between the perpendicular and parallel orientation, which is comparable to values obtained on an extended Py/Pt bilayer.40 An angular-dependent fit of the AMR data is obtained when assuming a coherent Stoner–Wohlfarth rotation of the magnetization with the external field H. The internal in-plane angle φint is then a solution of the equation: sinðφ φintÞ ¼ Hk 2H
sinð2φintÞ, and yields a best fit with the relatively strong uniaxial anisotropy field μ0Hk of 41 mT along the ŷ-axis. This uniaxial anisotropy clearly stems from an additional shape anisotropy induced by the constriction along the current path. As our microwave measurements below rely on a change in resistance arising from the auto-oscillating magnetization, we want to avoid the local resistance minimum at φ = 0°. To that end, we utilize an in-plane angle of φ = 24° for all measurements, which results in operation at a large slope of the resistance, dR/dφ. Furthermore the applied field is tilted with an out-of-plane angle θ between 40° and 80° for the electrical microwave measurements. The electrical current and magnetic field are applied in relative directions from each other as shown in Fig. 1(a) resulting in an effective negative damping from the spin current into the Py layer.
For the microwave emission measurements the SHNOs are connected to a dc current source via a bias-tee and the resulting microwave electrical signals are captured by a spectrum analyzer after amplification with a +32 dB low-noise amplifier. We limit the maximum current to 1.2 mA, since gradual and irreversible changes in the output characteristics could be observed above this point for another device, presumably due to electro-migration. Microwave emission data for several outof-plane angles are shown in Fig. 2.
A color plot of the logarithmic power spectral density is shown in Fig. 2(a) for an applied field of 0.7 T with an out-ofplane angle of 60°. Starting from the threshold current Ith = 0.54 mA the oscillation frequency first increases linearly with a

The auto-oscillation frequency is always well below the ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) frequency of the extended thin film, 18.4 GHz, calculated using the magnetostatic boundary conditions with a measured effective magnetization of μ0Meff = 0.74 T. Therefore, we conclude that the resulting magnetodynamic mode is spatially localized, which is also consistent with our simulation results discussed later.
In Fig. 2(b)–(d) we show how the auto-oscillation frequency ( f ), power (P) and linewidth (Δf ) vary with current for five different out-of-plane field angles, as determined from fits of a single Lorentzian to the measured power spectral density. We can first conclude that the frequency increases rapidly when tilting the field towards the in-plane direction, in accordance with the FMR frequency of obliquely magnetized thin films. Secondly, the threshold current has a minimum at about 60° and then increases significantly for both higher and lower out-of-plane field angles, as plotted in the inset of Fig. 2(a). The apparent minimum is likely a consequence of an angulardependent intrinsic threshold current for auto-oscillations and the gradual loss of AMR as the equilibrium magnetization
angle approaches the film normal. However, starting from the threshold current, the integrated output power increases exponentially with an apparently angle-independent exponential factor, see Fig. 2(c). A similar behavior is observed for the linewidth, Fig. 2(d), decreasing exponentially at a universal rate starting from each threshold current for θ ≥ 60°. However, the linewidth in the case of θ = 50°, shows a near constant value, while for θ = 40° it even increases for most of the time after a sharp initial decrease. This change in behavior might be related to a transition between the non-linear localized mode observed for high tilting angles and a linear FMR-like mode, observed previously for smaller in-plane applied fields.43 This is further corroborated by the fact that the auto-oscillation for θ = 40° vanishes for higher currents. In our case of strongly tilted fields, the minimum linewidth is 1.5 MHz, which is a significant improvement compared to the 6 MHz previously reported. Additionally to the improved linewidth and a reduction of the bias current by more than a factor of 3, our maximum integrated output power of 4.5 pW is still within the same level of previous nano-constriction-based SHNOs.43

The integrated output power of the auto-oscillation, Fig. 3(b), increases only slightly over the measurement range, while the linewidth decreases by one order of magnitude, see Fig. 3(c). The increase in oscillation frequency and the simultaneous decrease of the linewidth result in a drastic improvement of the quality factor f /Δf of up to ∼2000 in Fig. 3. In a 60° tilted field, we can observe numbers of up to 8000. Both numbers are higher than the value of ∼800 obtained from the nanoconstrictions measured in an in-plane field in ref. 43 and comparable to values reported for NC-STOs operated in very high magnetic fields.50 Larger out-of-plane fields are accompanied by a gradual tilting of the magnetization away from the plane, resulting in a reduced negative non-linearity of the ferromagnetic film, which is known to have a large influence on the linewidth of a spin torque oscillator.23,38
The nature of the auto-oscillations are further investigated by micromagnetic simulations. Firstly, the current distribution in the device, as well as the current-generated Oersted field, are obtained by COMSOL Multiphysics (http://www.comsol. com) in a finite-size element 3D model of the bilayer with a meshing size smaller than 1 nm in the nanoconstriction. These distributions are then used as inputs for the GPU-accelerated micromagnetic simulation code mumax3,51 which simulates in a volume of 4000 × 4000 × 5 nm3 discretized into 1024 × 1024 × 1 cells. The micromagnetic simulations take into account only the permalloy free layer and a standard material parameter for its exchange stiffness A = 12 pJ m−1 was used, as well as parameters determined from our actual bilayer by co-planar waveguide based FMR,52 namely Gilbert damping α = 0.02 and the effective magnetization μ0M = 0.74 T. The utilized spin Hall angle 0.07 as a conversion ratio between charge current in the Pt layer and the pure spin current acting on the Py layer36,53 yields a remarkable agreement between simulation and experiment. The simulations were performed assuming the temperature T = 300 K.
The power spectral density of the simulated device as obtained from fast Fourier transformation of 60 ns time traces of the average magnetization is plotted in Fig. 4(a) and shows a good qualitative agreement with the experimental data, cf. Fig. 2(a), regarding the current tunability and the threshold current. Oppositely to the experimentally and micromagnetically observed region of blue-shifting (df /d|I| > 0) near the threshold current, analytical calculations on localized excitations predict a red-shifting (df /d|I| < 0).54 However, the positive current tunability observed for our ultra-small nanoconstrictions can be understood by considering all magnetic field contributions: (i) the Oersted field generated from the current flowing in the top Pt layer and (ii) the demagnetizing field due to the finite lateral size of the Py free layer in the constriction.43 The Oersted field has an in-plane component directed dominantly opposite to the external applied field, thus decreasing the effective magnetic field and out-of-plane tilt angle of the magnetization as the current is increased.
Therefore, an additional negative current tunability can be expected from the Oersted field. Similar to the Oersted field, the demagnetizing field is oriented oppositely to the external magnetic field and reduces the effective magnetic field. However, starting at the onset of auto-oscillations, the precessional motion of the magnetization decreases the static magnetization and in-turn also reduces the average demagnetizing field acting inside the nano-constriction. Thus, a positive current tunability is expected from the reduction of the demagnetizing field with increasing auto-oscillation amplitude. The x-components of the Oersted field and the average demagnetizing field at the center (x = y = 0 nm) of our simulated device as obtained from COMSOL and micromagnetic simulations, respectively, are shown as an inset of Fig. 4(a). An agreement between the effective current tunability and the role of both magnetic field components is clearly visible in the micromagnetic simulations and corroborates the experimentally observed frequency dependence at threshold as well as the near-zero tunability around 1.1 mA.
Evaluating the micromagnetic simulations with regards to the time-averaged magnetization in the center leads to an important difference between the case of θ = 60° on the one hand, as shown in Fig. 4, and lower out-of-plane field angles

SHNOs operated in an in-plane magnetic field are known to have their time-averaged magnetization locally switched.55 While in our simulations for θ = 60° this assumption is not the case, the magnetization is initially expected to be locally switched in simulations with the applied field along 50° and 40° and sufficiently large currents. The currents at which this switching is expected correlate approximately with the experimentally observed points where the linewidth increases or the signal disappears, respectively. This presumed magnetization switching and the concomitant nonuniform magnetization state can thus be the source of an additional STT due to a part of the charge current flowing in the permalloy layer.56 Indeed, micromagnetic simulations with an additional current-induced torque lead to disruptive effects for θ = 40° and I = 1.1 mA, which prevent stable oscillations, but show no changes for angles above 60°, in agreement with the experimental observations.
By taking fast Fourier transforms for each simulation cell and plotting the amplitude for the oscillation frequency f = 17.57 GHz, the spatial distribution of the oscillation magnitude at a simulated current of 1.1 mA can be determined, as shown in Fig. 4(b). A localized mode with an extent of approximately 200 nm along the current path is found, thus being somewhat larger than the length of the constricted area.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, we have shown the fabrication of nano-constriction-based SHNOs with a minimum dimension of 20 nm. The auto-oscillations are detected electrically and exhibit high spectral purity over a wide range of applied magnetic field strengths and out-of-plane angles. The ultra-small dimensions lead to a significant decrease in operating currents with thresholds well below 1 mA in out-of-plane tilted external magnetic fields. A strong, effectively uniaxial, anisotropy field induced by the lateral confinement can be potentially used as a parameter for tuning the device’s frequency via changes in the in-plane direction of the applied field. Micromagnetic simulations provide additional insights regarding the magnetodynamics, including the spatial extent of the excited mode and the observed variation in the current tunability and how it is dependent upon both the shape-induced demagnetizing field at the center of the nano-constriction and the Oersted field.

metadata.abstractText: Spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNOs) are an emerging class of pure spin current driven microwave signal generators. Through the fabrication of 20 nm nano-constrictions in Pt/NiFe bilayers, we demonstrate that SHNOs can be scaled down to truly nanoscopic dimensions, with the added benefit of ultra-low operating currents and improved power conversion efficiency. The lateral confinement leads to a strong shape anisotropy field as well as an additional demagnetizing field whose reduction with increasing autooscillation amplitude can yield a positive current tunability contrary to the negative tunability commonly observed for localized excitations in extended magnetic layers. Micromagnetic simulations corroborate the experimental findings and suggest that the active magnetodynamic area resides up to 100 nm outside of the nano-constriction.
